title: data.world: A Platform for Global-Scale Semantic Publishing
segmentation: So what is what is data that world?
It's a collaborative.
Data platform the vast majority of our users on our platform are not semantic web experts.
They're not really aware of semantic web.
They don't use it day-to-day.
Most of the datasets are coming in the platform are not published as linked data.
There are mostly tabular data, tabular data, Jason documents coming into the platform.
We use web standards, specifically CSV W to convert that data into RDF.
So if you come to the platform and bring RDF native data.
We work great with that.
We can help kind of identify what ontologies you're using.
Help give you a sparkle endpoint over that data immediately, but we also deal with any tabular data.
Formats you bring.
We build an RDF model out of that using using CSV W and give you and give you capabilities to query that data in place as well.
Every data set gets a sparkle endpoint where they did it in that data set as the default graph.

Any other data set in the platform that you have access to is iaccessible and and graph, so you can effectively think of data DOT World is a giant quad squad store where every every data set that you are permitted to see is accessible to name graph and then obviously you can federate out with something.
Service query to talk outside of the platform.
So why did we build it?
I think a lot more people should care about the semantic web and the real question is why don't they?
And you know, there is definitely a perception that that semantic product's come off sometimes as a solution in search of a problem.

If you talk to folks who are working with the mainstream data data work, they're not interested in any solution that starts with hey, first, learn all about RDF and ontologies, and then we're going to these great things that you can do with it.
You know, we felt there was a real opportunity to go out and find the actual take.
The problems that people doing mainstream data work are seeing and show them solutions that can use semantic technology.
But still the operate in familiar modes.
Percent of data science is time is spent finding and preparing.

They say there's not commonly accepted standards among most of the people working with data for how to capture the knowledge that they've gained went on a project.
They've taken a set of data sources and made them work together.
Semantic web is actually great for that.
I know everyone here knows that most of the people in the world do not know that, and So what we're trying to do is basically build a set of tools that work the way most people are.
You are working with data that uses that technology to help to address that.
Projects tend to have a huge, diverse set of people working on it at one end of the spectrum you will have knowledge engineers who are building ontologies and actually and curating knowledge bases.
You've got data scientists doing analysis analysts who are more comfortable working in spreadsheets and visual analytics platforms like Tableau.
People who just want to see the final output, the reports, the dashboards, all those folks have a process in a toolchain they prefer they're not interested in.
Let me first teach you how to do everything you do in RDF instead, but if you use an RDF model as.
As a way to standardize and normalize the data and use that as the hub, bring bring all those folks together with tools that they are familiar with.
You can actually.
You can actually make a lot of headway.
And you know finally, just working.
It is not a one way conversation.

That's absolutely the right way to do things for that highly curated data.
Most of the data that people are working on is more fluid.
It's more changing.
There's a there's a lot of different models of who can.
Who owns that data, who can write that data, how it could be manipulated, and so you know a platform that really wants to address all all of those data needs.

Because most of the data is tabular.
And many, many more people know SQL than Sparkle.
We've leveraged the CSV W model which still retains the columnar tabular column and row structure of the data.
To be able to implement a in SQL engine that actually compiles SQL queries into Sparkle, I realized for almost everyone here that seems completely backwards.
There's usually there's a lot of work being done going the other way.
We get a lot of leverage out of the fact that the internal model is all the consistent sparkle engine for querying, but people can write SQL queries that can join.

By and large, we're not doing something I would consider anyone, I just I assume you would think is you know, pushing the envelope on inventing new semantic technology.
We you know we are primarily taking the semantic technology and building features that are more familiar to mainstream data workers using it.

Somewhat novel is our query architecture.

We have a lot of free users.
We want to be able to support that forever.

We're not the most performant Sparkle query engine, it's but it is good enough performance.
Optimized for scale, we use HTTP which is developed by the folks here at University of Vienna, where we've had a lot of great interactions with them.
The query architecture from very simple level are.
Run inquiry servers.
Parse user queries if their SQL queries.
That's where we converted into sparkle.
If there's sparkle queries, we parse them so that we can route them to the right tier of of use internally.
That second tier of servers are running just raw sparkle as it's handed to them.
Their job is really to pull those HTT files up into the fast disk layer where we can.
We can run those queries and then finally as things age out of the cash, they're stored in extremely cheap cloud storage.
So if there's a version of a data set or data set that hasn't been touched in months, it's not going to be.
It's going to using the smallest amount of resources possible.
So we can load that back up on demand.
Things we're working on now.
We're we're building a lot more tools to enrich data with schema metadata, and entity reconciliation.
We have a good amount of that in the platform already.
This is kind of the most active area, so our team is pushing features out here every single week.
We have a lot of capabilities in the platform based on based on things you would be familiar with.
A lot of our work is really just doing a lot of user centered design.

We gotta talk to a lot of people doing data work and find ways that we can get them to understand what they're doing when they're when they're telling us about the knowledge that they know about about a column about a variable about a data set.
Are any browser enhancements we we have a link data browser that you that would be very familiar for any kind of linked open data web web web platform.

We are finding a lot of interest in using building better HTML smart HTML templates around the actual types and taxonomies of the data to help people turn their Excel spreadsheets and databases into linked data models into browsable web interfaces that are that they could expose to their user.
We have a lot more work to do in terms of how we help people solve problems with data set, versioning, auditing, governance.

Every changes is completely attracted.
Every change is is is is is.

Again the work there is really how do we.
How do we do that?
How do we expose this in a way that makes sense?
It's very natural to how most people are thinking about.
About managing data.
Finally, you know the HDD.
The best query architecture works great for scaling out exploratory queries.
It's not great for large analytical, non selective types of queries.
Again, we're working with folks with folks at here.
We want to get as much leverage as we cannot HTTP, and there's, you know, there's some standard ways of addressing these kind of performance problems.

We were starting to explore with maybe building parquet files or some other columnar format for long, skinny, tabular data and routing those segments of those queries to a different engine just to wrap up.
You know we started the company based on hypothesis.
Is that to increase the size and connectivity of web link data we need to get more people involved.

We need to get the people who are actually out there doing a lot of work in data involved in building the web link data and we think that by using semantic web tech to facilitate the work that people are already doing, people are already doing knowledge engineering work.
They just don't call it that.
They just don't know that's what they're doing.
This is a great medium to start to capture that work back and bring those people into awareness of semantic web.
